description: {"blocks":[{"key":"1jvpk","text":"Photography is among one of the most widely used methods in scientific publications to efficiently and objectively communicate morphological, technological and aesthetic characteristics of any object. Particularly, in the fields of archaeology and anthropology, the study of small objects and artefacts is fundamental for the better understanding of past and present human activities. For these purposes, photography offers a method for researchers and alike to use photographs as objective evidence for their findings, results and interpretations. Here, the Small Object and Artefact Photography (SOAP) protocol is presented. This protocol aims to offer a standardised and full-encompassing method for the most objective and scientifically reproducible application of photography for academic purposes. The protocol follows an optimised step-by-step method, presenting the practice of small object and artefact photography from the initial set up of the equipment, the best methods for camera handling and functionality use, to the application of post-processing softwares. This method has been developed for anyone interested in producing clear and high quality photographs for a multitude of applications, from academic and scientific publications to public outreach.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"elcbm","text":"In the following protocol, typographical emphases and brackets have been used for software and in-text references. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6m7eu","text":"They are: (1) software features and tools written in bold, e.g. lock or Rectangle Tool; (2) \"layers\" in \"quotation marks\", e.g. \"background\"; (3) references to steps of the protocol in italics, e.g. step 21; (4) \u003ckeyboard buttons\u003e in \u003cangle markers\u003e, e.g. \u003cright click\u003e or \u003cDel\u003e; and (5) computational workflows  linked by angle markers (\u003e), e.g. \u003cright click\u003e \u003e Arrange \u003e Bring to Back.\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":64,"length":5},{"style":"bold","offset":72,"length":14},{"style":"italic","offset":185,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":199,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"28ada","text":"Please note: This protocol has been developed for Adobe® Photoshop®, being specifically developed using Adobe® Photshop® 2021. Nevertheless, previous Adobe® Photoshop® versions and other vector graphics softwares can be used (e.g. GIMP®). If previous versions or different softwares are being used, some functionalities will have to be accessed and applied differently.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fo541","text":"If a tripod or camera mount cannot be used, make sure to grip the camera properly, following these instructions:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1nbna","text":"Use both hands (right hand on camera grip, left hand under lens)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79omc","text":"Stabilise whole body (rest camera-holding arm on knee or solid surface, or lean whole body against surface)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aq3l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfdhc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6oek8","text":"The colour of the background should be complementary to the main colour of the artefact or object being photographed. The best colour for the background will make the subject stand out. This will make it easier later in the process to colour balance the image and remove the background digitally.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"cd2sv","text":"Place artefact flat onto the workspace.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2bu7n","text":"Select image raw format.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43bvf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bc12a","text":"RAW image formats (CR2, CRW, NEF, PEF...) are always preferred as they undergo the least amount of digital processing, with little to no loss of visual details.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33a3b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"332md","text":"Other formats can also be used if very high resolution photos are not necessary, and they are:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fgcuq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6bal8","text":"Tagged Image Files (TIF/TIFF): Large files which do not loose much visual quality by using the so-called \"loss-less\" compression. Alternatively, photo filters can be used to achieve a linear adjustment, although they require subjective judgement.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8v3bl","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4fbq3","text":"If the method described here is used for scientific publication, we suggest disclosing that this manipulation technique was used.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7meej","text":"Finally, using the Lasso Tool, \u003cright click\u003e on the subject, and select Layer via copy...","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":19,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":72,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d93a3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3td5b","text":"This will create a separate layer, with the final subject correctly isolated and ready for finalisation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ae28e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bjipc","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"fbu3k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"91A29A902DC611ECAF70DDCF717D3408","height":323.49636363636324,"id":215618,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6i81j","text":"Result after background removal.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guuebgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guucbgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guudbgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guubbgrsx.webp","width":348.1859099804302}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"73bsb","text":"To include a background, create a new \"layer\", and draw the background using the Rectangle Tool. Keeping in mind Step 3, select the best suited colour as a background.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":81,"length":14},{"style":"italic","offset":113,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6q6t0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5a5cn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b51pl","text":"To add a scale activate the \"layer\" of original photograph. Use the Rectangle Tool or Line Tool to trace the original photographed scale to the desired length, hence creating a new object which will be the final scale of choice.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":68,"length":14},{"style":"bold","offset":86,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d4utp","text":"Using the Rectangle Tool, Line Tool, Elipse Tool, Pen Tool, or any other preferred tool, add any symbols of choice (e.g. dotted line for wear, arrow for percussion point)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":10,"length":14},{"style":"bold","offset":26,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":37,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":50,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8bg0h","text":"Repeat Steps 22-25 for any other subject of choice.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":7,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8j6dm","text":"Once all the items of choice are included in a single canvas, position them in their final position and add connectors if you wish (using the Line Tool or Rectangle Tool).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":142,"length":10},{"style":"bold","offset":155,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7b5cm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"bt4pi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"32qh7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"buj03","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"ehr5m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":115,"style":"bold"}],"key":"atum5","text":"To help you with the positioning of the subjects in a single composition, you can use the Grid function. Also, the Transform Tool will let you resize objects. For the latter, make sure to resize while keeping the size ratio uniform (hold \u003cShift\u003e key), and always resize the relevant scale together with the subject.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"B635D9802E7011EC8C40B553D8D56833","height":283.2709090909091,"id":215622,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ftq0k","text":"Example of scale formats and symbols.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"protocol.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guuibgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guugbgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guuhbgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/guufbgrsx.webp","width":388.52618453865335}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"90pl0","text":"On Adobe® Photoshop® a variety of export formats can be selected. The most common are: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"r5h2","text":"
","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4476i","text":"1. .TIF/TIFF (File > Save as… > Save as type: > TIFF)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5smq6","text":"
","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bpoft","text":"2. .JPG (File > Export > Export as… > Save as type: > JPEG)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6st27","text":"
","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6odj","text":"3. .PNG (File > Export > Export as… > Save as type: > PNG)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2bnaa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5qgkm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3133k","text":"4. .PSD/.PDD/.PSDT (File > Save as… > Save as type: > Photoshop) ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bdtoh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3ak4p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"akacd","text":".TIFF, .JPG, .PNG are useful formats once the image is finished. However, it is recommended to have a version saved on the native format of the image processing software used (i.e. .PSD on photoshop, .XCF on GIMP or equivalent) as that allows further processing of the image if required.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6amh6","text":"White Balance","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3cqke","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6r66n","text":"White balance is the adjustment of the colour temperatures captured by the lenses. On the camera, this is a process that can be adjusted in three ways: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7nhbj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bdl0a","text":"1. Automatic: Auto adjusted during capture","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ecbr0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3j74r","text":"2. Pre-set: Predetermined categories built in the camera (e.g. 'Cloudy', 'Incandescent', 'Direct Sunlight')","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"46t5m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ga33","text":"3. Manual: Some cameras come with the option to manually choose a colour temperature (Values in Kelvin)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rho9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4i19","text":"These on-camera options can be useful if a quicker acquisition and processing is required.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"41lfe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f315v","text":"Lastly, White Balance can be also changed on the Post Processing phase by: manually adjusting the values on post processing software (see step 18).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8qopd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"10sjp","text":"Arguably the most important part of a camera is the lens. Before continuing with this method, we suggest the reader understand what type of lenses exist and which one works best for its use. In this case, we suggest using a macro lens. Find below definitions and descriptions of Macro Lens and commonly used standard zoom lens:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhbs5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"anf18","text":"Macro Lens: A Macro Lens is a type of lens that allows very close up shots of the subject. In many cases, it requires close proximity to the subject being photographed but in return, it offers high levels of detail, which are difficult to be acquired with regular lens. This in turn, makes macro lens ideally suited for small object and artefacts photography.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tpev","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6bhle","text":"Standard Zoom Lens:  Standard Zoom Lens is a highly variable type of lens, allowing for the capture of landscapes, people, buildings and small objects and artefacts. Although it may not perform as well as a macro lens, its flexibility makes it an ideal lens for many archaeology professionals, projects and institutions, hence, one of the most commonly available lens types. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fei8v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3imha","text":"Ultimately, the choice of a lens should be reflected against the questions and needs of the archaeologist/photographer. If highly detailed close-up photographs are required, a Macro Lens is recommended, however, if illustrative photographs are required, a Standard Zoom Lens is more than capable to achieve good and usable photographs.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
